alert_summary.description: Dangerously cold wind chills (as low as -25°F to -30°F) through Saturday late morning; not directly a Monday closure driver but increases risk of lingering slick spots and equipment/starting issues.
Lake-effect snow and blowing snow impacts Friday; indicates active winter pattern but does not guarantee significant snow Monday.
River ice/ice jam risk due to prolonged bitter cold; not a school travel hazard unless local flooding develops.

meteorology.overall_conditions_summary: For Rockford, MI heading into the Monday 2026-01-26 school morning: the provided forecast window (Sun 2026-01-25) shows very cold temps staying well below freezing all day and night, with a burst of snow Sunday evening (~6–10 PM) totaling about 0.9". Snow appears to taper off before midnight, which is favorable for overnight plowing/road treatment ahead of the Monday commute. Winds are light (generally 5–8 mph) so blowing/drifting and major visibility restrictions look unlikely. Net impact: a minor snow event on top of existing winter conditions—more likely a normal (maybe slick) Monday rather than a snow day. Biggest travel risk would be localized untreated roads/parking lots refreezing hard due to single-digit temps, but amounts and timing do not strongly support closures in snow-tolerant West Michigan.

similar_weather_patterns.pattern_description: Light-to-moderate snow showers Sunday evening (Jan 25) with low totals (~1 inch / 2.2 cm), followed by very cold air and subfreezing pavement into Monday morning (Jan 26). This is a common West Michigan mid-winter setup where districts typically stay open unless roads glaze or a narrow heavier band sets up right at commute time.

Extreme cold episode (wind chills in the -20s to near -30°F) occurring in the days immediately before the school day, then easing slightly but remaining very cold (single digits/teens) by the target morning. Historically this raises cancellation risk more for student safety (bus stops, long waits) than for snow depth—especially if wind chills fall below about -15°F.

High-pressure / light-wind cold pattern with occasional snow showers. These patterns often produce 'manageable' road conditions because wind-driven blowing/drifting is limited; closures tend to be rare unless the timing hits the pre-dawn commute with a quick burst that overwhelms treatment.

seasonal_context.typical_conditions_for_date: Late January in Rockford (Kent County) is climatologically one of the more snow-prone and cold parts of the school year, but schools typically operate through routine snow showers and light accumulations. Closures more often come from (1) ice/glaze, (2) true blizzard conditions with poor visibility/drifting, or (3) extreme cold/wind chill thresholds that create safety issues at bus stops.
unusual_factors: There is an ongoing notable cold outbreak in West Michigan (NWS Extreme Cold Warning/Advisory in the area on Jan 23–24), which increases the chance that any moisture on roads refreezes and that morning bus-stop exposure becomes a decision factor.

Sunday (Jan 25) snow signal is present in the evening hours, but forecast total snow is modest (~2.2 cm / ~0.9 in). The bigger operational risk is 'flash-freeze' or slick spots rather than plowable depth.
Winds are relatively light in the Jan 25 forecast period (generally under ~10 mph), which reduces classic blowing/drifting closure risk.

local_microclimates: West Michigan can see sharp, banded snow variations (lake-effect or enhancement), where totals can differ substantially over a few miles. If a heavier band sets up over northern Kent County near the Sunday night–Monday morning window, actual impacts could exceed the 'daily total' guidance.

Urban/treated corridors closer to Grand Rapids tend to improve faster; outlying and more rural/north-of-town roads around Rockford can stay slick longer, especially with very cold temperatures limiting salt effectiveness.
infrastructure_considerations: Rockford area roads are generally well-serviced, so a ~1 inch snowfall by itself rarely triggers a closure. The decision becomes more sensitive if roads are icy at 5–7 AM Monday (Jan 26) or if the district has widespread bus routes on secondary roads.
With temperatures near/under ~15°F, road treatment effectiveness is reduced and crews may rely more on plowing/abrasives; this can prolong slick conditions even with light snow.
location_specific_factors.elevation_impact: Elevation differences are modest, but small terrain/river-valley effects can matter for localized fog/icing and shaded-road refreeze. Cold air pooling overnight can keep some spots icier into the morning commute.

history.confidence_assessment: Based on the provided data, the snow amount indicated for Sunday (Jan 25) is light (~0.9 inch) and winds are not strong, which historically points to a low snow-day likelihood for Monday (Jan 26) in Rockford. The main watch-out is the cold: with very low temperatures preceding the day and subfreezing conditions continuing, even minor snow or moisture can create widespread slick spots (especially bridges/overpasses and untreated roads) by the morning commute. Overall confidence is medium-low because we do not have the explicit Jan 26 hourly forecast; if Monday morning wind chills drop below roughly -15°F or snow rates increase near commute time, cancellation odds would rise materially.

safety_recommendations: Main concern for Monday 2026-01-26 is refreeze/black ice on untreated surfaces from light snow (about 2.2 cm / ~0.9 in) Sunday evening (2026-01-25 ~18:00–22:00) with temps staying well below freezing (~6–14°F).
Expect primary routes to be largely plowed/treated by 6–8 AM Monday, but watch for slick spots on bridges/overpasses, ramps, and shaded stretches (especially where weekend traffic is lighter).
Greatest risk is secondary neighborhood roads and rural connectors: intermittent packed snow and spotty treatment could slow buses and increase slide-off risk at stop-sign intersections and hills.

Plan for slower loading/unloading: bus stop areas, sidewalks, and school drive loops may have drifted/plowed-in snow and can glaze over overnight; prioritize early salting of entrances, crosswalks, and drop-off zones.
If districts have many buses on backroads, consider a delay (not necessarily a full closure) to allow daylight plus final pass of plows and to reduce black-ice risk during 6–8 AM.
Wind speeds look modest (generally under ~10 mph), so widespread blowing/drifting is unlikely; visibility impacts should be limited outside of any lingering snow showers.

Cold exposure for students at stops remains a concern (single digits to teens with wind chills below 0°F at times); ensure extra warming capacity on buses and encourage covered skin for walkers/waiters.

news.key_findings_summary: For Monday, Jan. 26, 2026 (Rockford, MI / Kent County), I did not find an official Rockford Public Schools closure/delay announcement yet. However, there are multiple high-signal indicators that the region is in an active, impactful winter pattern: (1) Kent County issued an official ‘dangerous cold’ public safety bulletin on Jan. 22, 2026, (2) NWS Grand Rapids-area reporting indicates Extreme Cold Warning conditions into the weekend plus a mention of another snow-maker Sunday night (a key timeline for Monday morning road conditions), and (3) nearby districts have already altered operations—Sparta closing on Fri 1/23 and Forest Hills canceling activities on 1/22 and running a prior cold-related delay. Net: community signals are ‘uncertain’ specifically for Mon 1/26, but the operational posture in surrounding districts and the Sunday-night-into-Monday window are worth watching closely.

infrastructure.overall_clearing_assessment: For Monday 2026-01-26 AM in Rockford (Kent County): the main issue is not extreme snowfall totals (your Sunday forecast totals ~2.2 cm / ~0.9 in), but persistent very cold pavement temps that keep packed snow/ice in place and reduce chemical effectiveness. Kent County Road Commission indicates 24-hour winter response and anticipates snow-covered/slippery roads during cold/blowing snow periods, so expect ‘drivable but not great’ conditions early Monday—especially on neighborhood streets and rural bus-route segments. A full district-wide snow day is possible but not a slam-dunk on snow amount alone; delays or selective cancellations for outlying/rural routes are more plausible if snow persists into late Sunday night and roads stay polished/icy by 6:30 AM.

critical_alerts.message: AUTOMATIC CLOSURE TRIGGER MET (API current): WeatherAPI shows current 'feels like' -20.9°F (below -20°F). This requires high-precision verification against other sources.

Major discrepancy: WeatherAPI current feels-like (-20.9°F) differs from NWS observed wind chill (-13°F) by ~7.9°F (close to the 10°F discrepancy threshold) and differs dramatically from consumer-app 'feels like' values shown in available Weather.com/WU snippets.
For the school day Monday 2026-01-26: both NWS and Weather.com 10-day show highs around 16°F; neither shows an extreme wind-chill value anywhere near -20°F for Monday in the text summary available.

webWeatherVerifier.verification_summary: Target school day is Monday, 2026-01-26 (future). Your WeatherAPI payload contains forecast details for Sunday 2026-01-25, plus current conditions for Fri 2026-01-23 13:00 showing feels-like -20.9°F. Cross-checking: NWS point forecast for 2 Miles S Rockford shows observed wind chill -13°F around 12:55 PM EST on 2026-01-23 and does not indicate extreme wind chills for Monday; its Monday forecast is a high near 16°F with chance of snow showers before 1pm. Weather.com 10-day similarly lists Monday 2026-01-26 as cloudy with high 16°F and W winds ~14 mph; the text shown does not indicate dangerously low wind chills on Monday. Available Weather.com hourly snippets show morning 'feels like' values generally above 0°F (not near -20°F) for the colder period shown. Weather Underground’s conditions page snapshot shows temp ~14°F and 'like 14°F' (but that snapshot timestamp is older and may not match the same moment as WeatherAPI/NWS). Net: the only sub -20°F feels-like value confirmed in the provided dataset is the WeatherAPI current value; the most authoritative web source checked (NWS) shows wind chill below zero but not below -20°F at the comparable time, and both NWS + Weather.com suggest Monday is cold but not at automatic-closure wind-chill levels.

final.decision_rationale:
PRE-DECISION CHECKLIST
1) Agreements across experts: All teams converge that this is primarily a light-snow + extreme-cold/refreeze setup (not a heavy snow/blizzard). Winds are modest; visibility impacts are limited; power outages are not a driver. Most believe “delay > closure” if anything.
2) Disagreements: The main conflict was the Web Weather Verifier’s ‘≤ -20°F feels-like’ trigger from WeatherAPI (Fri conditions) versus NWS/other sources not showing that extreme for Monday; and whether conditions “worsen” after midnight. Follow-up verification indicates no authoritative support for ≤ -20°F wind chills on Monday morning and no credible 4+ inch snow scenario for Rockford in the Sun night→Mon window.
3) Plow timing math: If snow ends ~22:00 Sun, there are ~8.5 hours until 06:30 Mon; if it ends ~00:00, ~6.5 hours. Infrastructure monitor says that’s typically enough for trunklines and most county primaries to be bus-passable, but residential/local streets likely remain snow-packed early—supporting delay risk, not an automatic closure.
4) Ice?: No explicit freezing rain/ice accretion signal. Ice risk is “moderate” via refreeze/black ice, not a glaze storm.
5) Neighboring districts: News intel re-scan did not find Mon 1/26 closures/delays posted by Rockford or nearby major districts (Forest Hills, Sparta, Cedar Springs, Northview, GRPS, Lowell). That removes the +15–20% closure bump.
6) Power outages: Low footprint (~0.02% county), stable—no override.
7) Wind chill confirmation: NWS observed wind chill Fri was ~-13°F and Monday forecast does not indicate dangerously low wind chills; no multi-source confirmation of ≤ -20°F for Monday AM.
8) What would make this wrong: (a) a narrow lake-effect band sets up after midnight into the 4–8 AM commute producing several inches locally, (b) widespread polished black ice on bus routes worse than expected, or (c) an unexpected Monday-morning cold/wind spike driving wind chills toward ≤ -20°F.

WEIGHTING (per directive):
- Meteorology (25%): Points strongly toward “manageable snowfall/timing” → lowers closure odds.
- Safety (20%): Moderate black-ice/secondary-road risk → nudges up slightly (delay more likely than closure).
- History (15%): Similar setups rarely close in Rockford area → lowers.
- News Intel (15%): No Mon closures confirmed; no buzz → lowers.
- Infrastructure (10%): Overnight window likely sufficient; residential streets lag → modest bump but not to closure.
- Power Grid (10%): Minimal outages → neutral.
- Web Verifier (5%): Confirms discrepancy; no authoritative Monday ≤ -20°F → removes ‘auto-trigger’ bump.

Final: 18% probability of a full Rockford snow day (closure). A 2-hour delay is the more plausible adverse outcome if black ice is widespread on secondary/local roads at 5–7 AM.

alternative_scenarios.scenario: Base case: school open (some slick spots; normal operations)
alternative_scenarios.impact: Caution on neighborhood roads/parking lots; minor delays in drop-off/arrival possible.

for_schools: Plan for OPEN, but pre-decision a DELAY playbook (early AM road check on bus-heavy backroads; be ready to call a 2-hour delay if widespread black ice is observed).
Prioritize treatment of: entrances, crosswalks, bus loops, and sidewalks; cold limits salt effectiveness—use abrasives where needed.
Run early route reconnaissance (or driver feedback) focused on hills, stop-controlled intersections, bridges/overpasses, and shaded rural connectors.
for_residents: Assume slick spots Monday 5–9 AM, especially on neighborhood roads/driveways/sidewalks; allow extra time.
Dress for very cold morning waits; limit exposed skin at bus stops.
If driving, increase following distance and watch for polished intersections and bridge decks.
for_authorities: Target pre-dawn treatment to secondary/local streets feeding school bus routes; focus abrasives on known slick intersections and hills.
If possible, publish any overnight road-condition advisories by ~05:30–06:00 to support school decision timing.
Monitor for localized lake-effect banding after midnight; if a band sets up, reallocate plows quickly to affected corridors.

positions.rationale:
Meteorologically, the setup supports a ‘slick morning’ scenario more than a true snow day. Snowfall totals are modest (~0.9") and concentrated Sunday evening, with weak winds limiting blowing/drifting and preserving visibility. The main operational hazard is persistent cold: any snowpack/compaction or residual moisture will not melt and can polish into ice overnight, especially on secondary roads, bridges, shaded areas, and parking lots. That can justify a 2-hour delay if road crews need extra time, but a full closure usually needs either heavier snow during the pre-dawn/commute hours, significant ice/glaze, or wind-driven visibility/drifting issues—none of which are strongly indicated in the provided forecast window.

Given typical West Michigan winter response and tolerance, I place snow-day (full closure) odds in the high-teens; delay odds would be higher than closure odds based on the cold + light snow timing.
keyFactors: Most impactful precip appears to be Sunday evening (Jan 25) roughly 6–10 PM, with total snow around ~0.9 in (2.2 cm). That timing usually allows plows/crews to catch up before the Monday (Jan 26) AM commute.
Winds look light (generally <10 mph in the provided period), so low risk of whiteout, major drifting, or rapid re-covering of treated roads.

Temperatures remain well below freezing (single digits to teens), which raises black-ice/refreeze risk on untreated roads/parking lots and reduces chemical treatment effectiveness—but this tends to drive delays more than full closures in West Michigan unless widespread icing is present.
No strong signal of heavy snow rates at the commute window in the provided hourly data (visibility mostly 6 mi / 10 km; peak hourly snow increments are modest).

Cross-source verification suggests Monday is cold but not at extreme-wind-chill closure thresholds (WebWeatherVerifier notes NWS/Weather.com show highs ~16°F for Mon Jan 26 and do not show extreme wind chills that day).

positions.rationale: As the history specialist, I anchor on how often Rockford-area districts actually cancel under similar setups: late-January light snow (<~1 inch) with low wind typically does not produce a snow day. The main pathway to a closure is cold-driven refreeze/black ice on secondary roads and bus-route connectors, but that more often produces a delay than a full closure unless conditions are widespread and untreated. Given the modest accumulation signal and favorable timing (Sunday evening), I place a low-but-nontrivial cancellation probability at 17% for Monday, Jan 26, 2026.
keyFactors: Historical baseline for Rockford/Kent County: ~0.9" (2.2 cm) snow with light winds is typically ‘school as normal’ in late January; closures are uncommon without heavier totals, ice, or blizzard-like visibility/drifting.

Timing is somewhat favorable for staying open: the main snow signal in the provided hourly data is Sunday evening (Jan 25 ~6–10 PM), leaving an overnight window for treatment/plowing before the Monday (Jan 26) commute.

Cold is the main historical wildcard: with single-digit/teen temps and very cold pavement, light snow can translate into persistent slick spots (bridges, shaded roads, untreated neighborhoods). Historically this pushes districts more toward delays than full closures unless widespread icing is observed.

Recent operational posture in the area (nearby districts already closing/delaying during this cold spell) slightly increases the odds that administrators are ‘risk-averse’ going into Monday, even if the meteorological trigger is marginal.

No strong historical “closure driver” signal for Rockford here: winds are light (limited drifting), snow totals are modest, and we don’t see an explicit Jan 26 morning heavy burst in the provided dataset.

positions.rationale: From a safety standpoint, this setup (light snow Sunday evening + very cold overnight) most often produces localized slick spots rather than system-wide impassable roads in West Michigan. That points to ‘open with caution’ or ‘delay’ more than a full snow day. I’m setting 18% for a full closure because the main pathway to cancellation would be: (a) secondary roads polishing over with widespread black ice by 5:30–7:30 AM Monday, or (b) the Sunday-night snow band overperforms and lays down more than ~1 inch in the district’s bus-heavy areas. Without a strong signal for heavy snow during the Monday commute, closure remains a minority outcome.
keyFactors: Snow amount/timing looks manageable for operations: Sunday 2026-01-25 shows ~2.2 cm (~0.9 in) mainly 6–10 PM, tapering before midnight, leaving several hours for treatment before Monday AM routes.

Safety risk is dominated by refreeze/black ice: temperatures stay well below freezing (single digits to teens) so any thin moisture film + compacted snow on low-volume roads can persist into the 6–8 AM bus window.
Winds are light (generally <10 mph in the Sunday forecast), so I’m not expecting widespread whiteout, drifting, or blowing-snow pileups to force closure.

Primary roads likely acceptable by commute; secondary/local streets are the limiting factor for buses—especially hills, stop-controlled intersections, and shaded stretches with reduced salt effectiveness at ~10°F.

Cold exposure at bus stops is a secondary safety driver, but current evidence does not support Monday (2026-01-26) wind chills consistently at the typical “auto-cancel” levels; more likely this pushes a 2-hour delay decision than a full closure.

positions.rationale:
As the NEWS specialist, I weight (a) official/earned-media signals that districts are primed to close, and (b) evidence of a disruptive event aligned with school decision timelines. Here, the strongest news signals are about an extreme cold episode and recent travel impacts region-wide, plus neighboring districts already taking weather actions earlier in the week. However, the meteorology and infrastructure peers converge on a light-snow Sunday-evening scenario with low wind and time for plowing before Monday morning, which historically produces delays more often than full closures in snow-tolerant West Michigan.

Given that (1) no official Rockford announcement is present yet, (2) the snow amount/timing looks manageable, and (3) Monday’s verified forecast does not point to extreme wind chills, I land in the “low but non-trivial” range: closures are possible if slick secondary roads/black ice become widespread at 5–7 AM Monday, but the base case is school open (maybe a delay).
keyFactors: No Rockford Public Schools closure/delay posted yet for Monday 2026-01-26; absence of early signaling usually correlates with “open unless conditions worsen overnight.”

Forecast-driven impacts look more like a nuisance event than a crippling one: ~0.9" snow Sunday evening (2026-01-25 ~6–10 PM) with light winds, giving road crews time to catch up before Monday commute.

Cold is the bigger “headline” risk driver in local messaging (Kent County bulletin; NWS extreme cold products), but the verified outlook suggests Monday itself is cold (high ~16°F) without extreme wind chills at typical auto-cancel thresholds.

Regional operational posture is elevated (nearby districts closed/delayed/canceled activities in the prior week), which slightly increases the chance of a delay/closure if Monday AM roads are slick—especially on secondary/rural routes.
No meaningful power-outage signal; so “infrastructure failure” is unlikely to force a closure on its own.

debates.topic: Your timing block labels worst conditions starting at 00:00–08:30 on Mon (Jan 26), but the provided hourly precip signal is mainly Sunday evening (Jan 25 ~18:00–22:00) and ends before midnight. debates.topic: Safety analysis flags worst conditions 00:00–08:30 Monday, but the meteorology feed suggests snow ends before midnight Sunday. If the hazard is primarily refreeze/black ice, the most likely operational outcome is a 2-hour delay rather than a full snow day—can we quantify that split (delay vs closure)?
debates.challenge: Safety analysis flags worst conditions 00:00–08:30 Monday, but the meteorology feed suggests snow ends before midnight Sunday. If the hazard is primarily refreeze/black ice, the most likely operational outcome is a 2-hour delay rather than a full snow day—can we quantify that split (delay vs closure)?

confidenceJourney.shiftReason:
Meteorologically, the setup supports a ‘slick morning’ scenario more than a true snow day. Snowfall totals are modest (~0.9") and concentrated Sunday evening, with weak winds limiting blowing/drifting and preserving visibility. The main operational hazard is persistent cold: any snowpack/compaction or residual moisture will not melt and can polish into ice overnight, especially on secondary roads, bridges, shaded areas, and parking lots. That can justify a 2-hour delay if road crews need extra time, but a full closure usually needs either heavier snow during the pre-dawn/commute hours, significant ice/glaze, or wind-driven visibility/drifting issues—none of which are strongly indicated in the provided forecast window.

Given typical West Michigan winter response and tolerance, I place snow-day (full closure) odds in the high-teens; delay odds would be higher than closure odds based on the cold + light snow timing.

As the history specialist, I anchor on how often Rockford-area districts actually cancel under similar setups: late-January light snow (<~1 inch) with low wind typically does not produce a snow day. The main pathway to a closure is cold-driven refreeze/black ice on secondary roads and bus-route connectors, but that more often produces a delay than a full closure unless conditions are widespread and untreated. Given the modest accumulation signal and favorable timing (Sunday evening), I place a low-but-nontrivial cancellation probability at 17% for Monday, Jan 26, 2026.

From a safety standpoint, this setup (light snow Sunday evening + very cold overnight) most often produces localized slick spots rather than system-wide impassable roads in West Michigan. That points to ‘open with caution’ or ‘delay’ more than a full snow day. I’m setting 18% for a full closure because the main pathway to cancellation would be: (a) secondary roads polishing over with widespread black ice by 5:30–7:30 AM Monday, or (b) the Sunday-night snow band overperforms and lays down more than ~1 inch in the district’s bus-heavy areas. Without a strong signal for heavy snow during the Monday commute, closure remains a minority outcome.

As the NEWS specialist, I weight (a) official/earned-media signals that districts are primed to close, and (b) evidence of a disruptive event aligned with school decision timelines. Here, the strongest news signals are about an extreme cold episode and recent travel impacts region-wide, plus neighboring districts already taking weather actions earlier in the week. However, the meteorology and infrastructure peers converge on a light-snow Sunday-evening scenario with low wind and time for plowing before Monday morning, which historically produces delays more often than full closures in snow-tolerant West Michigan.

Given that (1) no official Rockford announcement is present yet, (2) the snow amount/timing looks manageable, and (3) Monday’s verified forecast does not point to extreme wind chills, I land in the “low but non-trivial” range: closures are possible if slick secondary roads/black ice become widespread at 5–7 AM Monday, but the base case is school open (maybe a delay).

alert.headline: Hydrologic Outlook issued January 22 at 11:14AM EST by NWS Grand Rapids MI
alert.areas: Allegan, MI; Barry, MI; Calhoun, MI; Clare, MI; Clinton, MI; Eaton, MI; Gratiot, MI; Ingham, MI; Ionia, MI; Isabella, MI; Jackson, MI; Kalamazoo, MI; Kent, MI; Lake, MI; Mason, MI; Mecosta, MI; Montcalm, MI; Muskegon, MI; Newaygo, MI; Oceana, MI; Osceola, MI; Ottawa, MI; Van Buren, MI
alert.desc:
ESFGRR

Bitterly cold temperatures moving into Michigan over the next few
days will increase the risk of ice jams on rivers. While many
locations have already frozen over, ongoing ice growth will continue
to increase in any open water areas.

These temperatures have not been seen for many years in West
Michigan, which means that some areas that don't typically
experience river ice jams may have issues this year. Ice jams can
result in water levels rising much more quickly than usual, which
can catch people off guard. Anyone living or working near rivers in
West Michigan should prepare now for potential river ice and rising
water levels.

While temperatures warm up a bit early next week, this overall cold
weather pattern will continue through at least next week, which will
keep ice locked in place on the rivers.


You can always find the latest river level information at water.noaa.
gov

alert.headline: Extreme Cold Warning issued January 23 at 3:47AM EST until January 24 at 11:00AM EST by NWS Grand Rapids MI
alert.areas: Mason; Lake; Osceola; Clare; Oceana; Newaygo; Mecosta; Isabella; Muskegon; Montcalm; Gratiot; Ottawa; Kent; Ionia; Clinton
alert.desc:
* WHAT...Dangerously cold wind chills as low as 25 to 30 below.

* WHERE...Portions of central, south central, southwest, and west
central Michigan.

* WHEN...Until 11 AM EST Saturday.

* IMPACTS...These dangerously cold wind chills could cause frostbite
on exposed skin in 30 minutes or less. Frostbite and hypothermia
will occur if unprotected skin is exposed to these temperatures.
An extended period of freezing temperatures could cause ruptured
water pipes.
alert.instruction:
Avoid outside activities if possible. When outside, make sure you
wear appropriate clothing, a hat, and gloves. Keep pets indoors as
much as possible. Considering checking in on older family, friends,
and neighbors. Ensure portable heaters are used correctly. Do not
use generators or grills inside.

alert.headline: Winter Weather Advisory issued January 23 at 3:29AM EST until January 23 at 7:00PM EST by NWS Grand Rapids MI
alert.areas: Mason; Lake; Oceana; Newaygo; Muskegon; Ottawa; Kent; Allegan; Barry; Van Buren; Kalamazoo
alert.desc:
* WHAT...Snow. Additional snow accumulations up to two inches near
the lakeshore. Very poor visibilities in falling and blowing snow.

* WHERE...Portions of southwest and west central Michigan.

* WHEN...Until 7 PM EST this evening.

* IMPACTS...Roads, and especially bridges and overpasses, will
likely be slick and hazardous. Visibility and road conditions may
change rapidly over short distances in lake effect snow. The
hazardous conditions are expected to impact the Friday morning and
evening commutes.
alert.instruction:
Slow down and use caution while traveling.

During lake effect snow, the weather can vary from bands of locally
heavy snow to dry weather just a few miles away. Visibilities can
also vary greatly. Be prepared for rapid changes in weather,
visibility, and road conditions.

alert.headline: Cold Weather Advisory issued January 23 at 3:47AM EST until January 24 at 11:00AM EST by NWS Grand Rapids MI
alert.areas: Allegan; Barry; Eaton; Ingham; Van Buren; Kalamazoo; Calhoun; Jackson
alert.desc:
* WHAT...Very cold wind chills as low as 20 to 25 below.

* WHERE...Calhoun, Eaton, Ingham, Jackson, Allegan, Barry,
Kalamazoo, and Van Buren Counties.

* WHEN...Until 11 AM EST Saturday.

* IMPACTS...These dangerously cold wind chills could cause frostbite
on exposed skin in as little as 30 minutes. Frostbite and
hypothermia will occur if unprotected skin is exposed to these
temperatures.
alert.instruction:
